issues.description: Dr. Sarah Chen ‚Äî November 2024 Salary (20% FTE)

issue.title: No timesheet evidence for November 2024
issue.description: Staff cost charged at budgeted FTE (20%) with no timesheet evidence for November 2024. Dr. Chen is allocated across multiple grants and therefore requires monthly timesheet records under UKRI RGC 4.6.

ruleReference.source: UKRI fEC Grant Terms and Conditions
ruleReference.text: Where an individual is working on more than one project, the Research Organisation must maintain records of actual time spent on each project. Timesheets must be signed off and dated within 2 months of the end of the timesheet period.

issue.auditRisk: Without timesheet evidence, this cost is likely to be disallowed at UKRI Funding Assurance review. Including overhead recovery (60% of staff cost), total exposure is ¬£6,720.
recommendedActions: Obtain signed timesheet from Dr. Chen for November 2024
If timesheet unavailable, adjust charge to reflect actual documented hours
If variance exceeds 10% from budget, document justification
Move unevidenced portion to Task 89 (departmental cost) before FES submission

issues.description: Dr. James Okafor ‚Äî December 2024 Salary (30% FTE)

issue.title: Timesheet shows 22% FTE, billed at 30%
issue.description: December timesheet records 22% FTE on this grant, but payroll charged at budgeted 30%. This 8% variance represents ¬£1,680 potentially ineligible cost. UKRI requires actual costs, not budgeted estimates, for Directly Incurred staff.

ruleReference.source: UKRI fEC Grant Terms and Conditions Guidance
ruleReference.text: Directly incurred costs are explicitly identifiable as arising from the conduct of a project, charged as the cash value actually spent and supported by an audit record. Staff costs must be charged on an actual basis rather than budgeted.

issue.auditRisk: UKRI Funding Assurance has explicitly warned that charging staff costs on a budgeted basis is a common audit finding. The variance of ¬£1,680 plus overheads (¬£1,008) totalling ¬£2,688 will likely be disallowed.
recommendedActions: Adjust December charge from 30% to 22% to reflect actual timesheet
Process correcting journal: Credit ¬£1,680 to grant, Debit to departmental code
Review January allocation if similar pattern expected
Update budget forecast for remaining grant period

issues.description: Prof. Emma Walsh ‚Äî Q3 2024 Salary Recharge (15% FTE)

issue.title: Quarterly charge at budgeted rate with no actual time records
issue.description: Investigator time charged as Directly Incurred at budgeted 15% FTE for entire quarter. No actual time records maintained. Under TRAC guidance, investigator costs without auditable time records should be classified as Directly Allocated, not Directly Incurred.

ruleReference.source: UKRI fEC Grant Terms and Conditions Guidance
ruleReference.text: Where Investigator costs are based on estimates and therefore an auditable record cannot be provided, these costs should be charged as Directly Allocated. Directly Incurred costs must be supported by an audit record.

issue.auditRisk: This cost is miscategorised. As Directly Incurred without audit trail, full amount is at risk. If reclassified to Directly Allocated, the amount would be paid at the lesser of actual or budget, protecting the claim.
issue.exposureCalculation: Full quarterly charge ‚Äî no overhead exposure as investigator cost
recommendedActions: Reclassify from Directly Incurred (Task 1) to Directly Allocated (Task 2)
Implement prospective timesheet or time allocation for Prof. Walsh
Review all investigator costs on grant for consistent treatment
Document methodology if using estimated time allocation

issue.title: General-purpose computing equipment charged as Direct Cost
issue.description: iPad Pro purchased and charged as Directly Incurred equipment. General-purpose computing devices are typically considered indirect costs unless dedicated solely to the project with documented justification. No project-specific justification on file.

ruleReference.text: Computing equipment may be included under directly incurred only if dedicated to the project. General purpose computing equipment that could be used for other activities should be covered by indirect costs.

issue.auditRisk: Without documented project-specific justification, this cost will likely be disallowed as it should be covered by the institution's indirect cost recovery. Full amount at risk.
issue.exposureCalculation: Full purchase price ‚Äî no overhead as equipment
recommendedActions: Document specific project use case (e.g., dedicated data collection device)
If general use, recode to departmental equipment budget
Obtain retrospective approval from PI confirming dedicated project use
For future purchases, include justification in purchase requisition

issue.title: Equipment purchased in final months of grant
issue.description: MacBook Pro purchased in Month 35 of a 36-month grant. Late equipment purchases, particularly computing equipment, attract scrutiny as they may not contribute meaningfully to the funded research before the grant ends.

ruleReference.text: Directly incurred funds must not be used to meet the costs of an activity that will fall outside the grant period. Equipment purchased should be demonstrably required for research activities within the grant period.

issue.auditRisk: Equipment purchased in final grant months faces heightened audit scrutiny. Combined with lack of project-specific justification, this purchase is high risk for disallowance.
recommendedActions: Document specific research activities requiring this equipment before grant end
Provide written justification explaining timing of purchase
If cannot justify, recode to departmental equipment budget
Consider whether equipment should be returned to funder or retained under asset policy

issue.title: Non-itemised receipt ‚Äî cannot verify eligibility
issue.description: Amazon Business order description shows only 'Office Supplies' without itemisation. Audit requires itemised receipts to verify each item's eligibility. General office supplies (stationery, folders, etc.) should typically be covered by indirect costs.

ruleReference.text: Directly incurred costs must be supported by an audit record including itemised receipts or invoices. Non-itemised documentation does not provide sufficient audit trail.

issue.auditRisk: Without itemisation, auditors cannot verify eligibility. Items may include ineligible general office supplies. Medium risk of partial or full disallowance.
issue.exposureCalculation: Full amount at risk due to lack of itemisation
recommendedActions: Retrieve itemised receipt from Amazon Business account
Review items against eligible cost list
Recode any general office supplies to indirect cost centre
Implement policy requiring itemised receipts for all purchases

issue.title: General laboratory consumable ‚Äî likely indirect cost
issue.description: Laboratory notebooks are general consumables shared across multiple activities. UKRI guidance indicates general office and laboratory consumables should be covered by indirect costs, not charged as directly incurred.

ruleReference.source: UKRI fEC Grant Terms and Conditions Guidance
ruleReference.text: Indirect costs include general office and laboratory consumables. These are not directly related to any one project but are a necessary part of undertaking research activity.

issue.auditRisk: General consumables charged as direct costs may be flagged during audit. Lower risk than equipment, but pattern of such charges could trigger broader review.
recommendedActions: Review whether notebooks are project-specific (e.g., custom printed)
If general use, recode to departmental consumables budget
Document if notebooks are dedicated to specific grant activities
Review purchasing patterns for similar items

issue.title: General IT equipment ‚Äî requires justification
issue.description: External storage devices are general-purpose IT equipment. To be eligible as directly incurred, must be dedicated to project data storage with documented justification.

ruleReference.text: Computing costs including storage may be directly incurred only where dedicated to the project. General IT equipment should be covered by indirect costs.

issue.auditRisk: Without documented project-specific use, this purchase may be questioned. Lower value reduces audit priority but contributes to pattern.
recommendedActions: Document that drive is dedicated to project data (e.g., sensor recordings)
Label drive with grant reference for asset tracking
If general backup device, recode to departmental IT budget

issue.title: Conference not listed in approved travel plan
issue.description: NeurIPS 2024 conference registration charged to grant. Original grant application and approved travel plan identified different conferences (ICRA 2024, IROS 2024). Conference attendance should be individually identified and justified in the proposal.

ruleReference.text: Costs for attendance at conferences may be included, where such attendance will be of direct benefit to the research. Conferences should, as far as possible, be individually identified in the proposal and attendance justified.

issue.auditRisk: Attending conferences not in original proposal requires justification showing direct benefit to research. Without documentation, cost may be questioned.
recommendedActions: Document relevance of NeurIPS to grant research objectives
Note any papers presented or collaborations initiated
File justification with grant records for audit purposes
Consider whether GMR (Grant Maintenance Request) was needed

issue.title: Taxi receipts without journey purpose documentation
issue.description: Expense claim includes 7 taxi receipts totalling ¬£234.50. Journey purposes not documented on claim. UKRI requires travel costs to evidence value for money and direct relevance to project.

ruleReference.text: All travel claims should evidence value for money as the primary consideration. Evidence should include purpose of journey and relevance to project activities.

issue.auditRisk: Travel claims without documented purpose may be questioned. Taxi costs specifically scrutinised for value for money vs public transport alternatives.
recommendedActions: Request Dr. Okafor provide journey purposes retrospectively
Document why taxi was necessary vs public transport
Ensure future claims include journey details on submission
Review expense claim form to require mandatory journey purpose

issue.title: Sub-contracted work without deliverable evidence
issue.description: Consultancy payment made but no evidence of deliverables received. Sub-contracted work should be supported by contract, statement of work, and evidence of deliverable receipt.

ruleReference.text: Sub-contracted work will be subject to the procurement rules of the research organisation. Evidence of deliverables should be maintained for audit purposes.

issue.auditRisk: Payment without deliverable evidence may be questioned. Procurement compliance also requires competitive quotes for this value.
recommendedActions: Obtain and file deliverable (report, analysis output, etc.)
Ensure sub-contract agreement is on file
Verify procurement requirements were met (quotes if applicable)
Document how deliverable contributed to research objectives

issue.title: Participant payments without ethics approval on file
issue.description: Participant incentive payments made for user study. Grant records do not include copy of ethics approval. Research involving human participants requires documented ethics approval.

ruleReference.text: Research Organisations must ensure research is conducted according to appropriate ethical, legal and professional frameworks. Evidence of ethics approval should be maintained.

issue.auditRisk: Participant payments without ethics evidence create compliance risk beyond financial audit. Could trigger broader research governance review.
recommendedActions: Obtain copy of ethics approval and file with grant records
Verify all participant consent forms are retained
Confirm participant payment methodology was approved
Review whether ethics approval reference should be on invoices
